floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This flood warning has been issued as tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Waves and spray combined with strong winds and high tidal level are forecast to overtop coastal frontages in Hornsea, and could affect North Promenade, Marine Drive, South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck between 01:30am and 03:45am tomorrow morning, Sunday 30th January 2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Consider activating any property flood protection products if you have them. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 30th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning, Sunday 30th January.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. Areas most at risk are in Reedham, Cantley and Brundall. Roads affected include Ferry Road in Reedham, the A47 and the railway line between Reedham and Brundall.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 30th January.

This message has been issued because some flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 4:15am and 8:15am on Sunday 30th January.  Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to Storm Malik.  The location most at risk of flooding is the A12 at Blythburgh. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.22 mAODN at 6:15am, Sunday 30th January, which is 1.44m above tide tables, wind Force5, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  We will update this message by 10am on Sunday 30th January.

items.description: Isolated low lying properties along the tidal River Waveney
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning, Sunday 30th January.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. Areas most at risk are in St Olaves, Somerleyton, Burgh St Peter, Oulton Broad and Beccles. Roads likely to be affected include Beccles Road at St Olaves, Geldeston Lock Lane, Gillingham Dam and Fen Lane in Beccles. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 30th January.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this evening, Saturday 29th January, and tomorrow morning, Sunday 30th.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 30th January.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Skipton, Hornsea and Mappleton has been issued for tomorrow morning's tide, Sunday 30th January 2022, between 01:30am and 03:45am. Strong winds are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular area at risk is North Hornsea promenade. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected over the coming days and it is likely this alert will stay in force. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 30th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea has been issued for tomorrow morning's tide, Sunday 30th January 2022, between 03:15am and 04:30am. Strong winds and surge are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular area at risk is Kilnsea. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected over the coming days and it is likely this alert will stay in force. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 30th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber Estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall has been issued for tomorrow morningâ€™s tide, Sunday 30th January 2022, between 02:15am and 04:45am. The particular area of concern is Kilnsea village. Overtopping waves and spray are expected with flooding to roads and farmland possible between these times.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads in the Kilnsea area.  Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 30th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 4:15am and 8:15am on Sunday 30th January.  Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to Storm Malik.  We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.22 mAODN at 6:15am, Sunday 30th January, which is 1.44m above tide tables, wind Force 5, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  We will update this message by 10am on Sunday 30th January.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning, Sunday 30th January. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update messages when necessary.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 30th January.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning, Sunday 30th January. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.   Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 30th January.

Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides for the next tide. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and update you if the situation changes.
